meanings.def: to break without dividing into separate parts; to break something in this way
examples: The ice cracked as I stepped onto it.
crack something He has cracked a bone in his arm.
The dish had cracked quite badly.
The leather/​mud/​paint/​plaster had cracked.

meanings.def: to break open or into pieces; to break something in this way
examples: + adv./prep. A chunk of the cliff had cracked off in a storm.
(figurative) His face cracked into a smile.
crack something to crack a nut
crack something + adv./prep. She cracked an egg into the pan.

meanings.def: to hit something/somebody in a short hard manner
examples: I cracked my head on the low ceiling.
He cracked me on the head with a ruler.
He stood up suddenly, cracking his head on the low ceiling.
As I leapt up, I cracked my skull on a beam and passed out.

meanings.def: to make a sharp sound; to make something do this
examples: A shot cracked across the ridge.
[no passive] crack something He cracked his whip and galloped away.

meanings.def: if your voice cracks, it changes in depth, volume, etc. suddenly and in a way that you cannot control
examples: In a voice cracking with emotion, he told us of his son's death.

meanings.def: to no longer be able to function normally because of pressure
examples: Things are terrible at work and people are cracking under the strain.
They questioned him for days before he cracked.
The old institutions are cracking.
He is under a lot of pressure but is showing no signs of cracking.
The stresses of her job became too great and she finally cracked.

meanings.def: to find the solution to a problem, etc; to find the way to do something difficult
examples: to crack the enemy’s code
(informal) After a year in this job I think I've got it cracked!
‘How's the investigation going?’ ‘I think we've cracked it.’
A team of experts finally cracked the code.
We need some more solid evidence if we're going to crack the case.

meanings.def: to find a way of stopping or defeating a criminal or an enemy
examples: Police have cracked a major drugs ring.

meanings.def: to open a bottle, especially of wine, and drink it
to tell a joke
to use your authority or power to make somebody work very hard, usually by treating them in a strict way
to make jokes
examples: This entertainer can crack wise with the best of them.

meanings.def: to begin immediately and work quickly
examples: There's a lot to be done, so let's get cracking.

meanings.def: a difficult problem or situation to deal with
not as good as people say
examples: He's not nearly such a good writer as he's cracked up to be.

meanings.def: to use more force than is necessary

idioms.def: to use your authority or power to make somebody work very hard, usually by treating them in a strict way

examples: This entertainer can crack wise with the best of them.

idioms.def: to begin immediately and work quickly
examples: There's a lot to be done, so let's get cracking.

idioms.def: a difficult problem or situation to deal with

idioms.idiom: not all, everything, etc. somebody’s cracked up to be
idioms.def: not as good as people say
examples: He's not nearly such a good writer as he's cracked up to be.

idioms.idiom: use a sledgehammer to crack a nut
idioms.def: to use more force than is necessary

related: a fair crack of the whip

meanings.def: a line on the surface of something where it has broken but not split into separate parts
examples: This cup has a crack in it.
Cracks began to appear in the walls.
(figurative) The cracks (= faults) in the government's economic policy are already beginning to show.
A fine crack ran up the wall.
We filled the cracks in the plaster before hanging the wallpaper.
Wide cracks appeared in the ground during the drought.

meanings.def: a narrow space or opening
examples: She peeped through the crack in the curtains.
The door opened a crack (= a small amount).
Could you open the window just a crack?
There's a crack in the fence big enough to look through.
a tiny crack of light under the door

meanings.def: a sudden loud noise
examples: There was a deafening crack of thunder and the heavens opened.
She heard the sharp crack of a rifle shot.
A loud crack echoed off the empty walls.
He gave a crack of laughter.
The chandelier hit the floor with a crack.

meanings.def: a sharp, hard hit that can be heard
examples: She fell over and got a nasty crack on the head.

meanings.def: an occasion when you try to do something
examples: She hopes to have another crack at the world record this year.
He had a good crack at opening the door, but it wouldn't budge.

meanings.def: a powerful, illegal drug that is a form of cocaine
examples: a crack addict

meanings.def: a joke, especially a critical one
examples: He made a very unfair crack about her looks.
He gets really mad if anyone makes a crack about his weight.

meanings.def: a good time; friendly, lively talk
examples: Where's the crack tonight?
He's a person who enjoys a drink and a bit of crack.

meanings.def: very early in the morning
examples: I have to get up at the crack of dawn.

meanings.def: a reasonable opportunity to show that you can do something
examples: I felt we weren't given a fair crack of the whip.

meanings.def: when somebody/something falls or slips through the cracks, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them
examples: We tried to contact all former students, but one or two slipped through the cracks.
I have to get up at the crack of dawn.

idioms.idiom: a fair crack of the whip
idioms.def: a reasonable opportunity to show that you can do something
examples: I felt we weren't given a fair crack of the whip.

idioms.def: when somebody/something falls or slips through the cracks, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them
examples: We tried to contact all former students, but one or two slipped through the cracks.

meanings.def: expert and highly trained; excellent at something
examples: crack troops
He's a crack shot (= accurate and skilled at shooting).
